opener.salute: Monsieur le Vice-Amiral Prince de Nassau-Siegen,

body.p: j'ai reçu hier Votre lettre en date de la rade de Cronstadt du 3 Juin, par laquelle vous me faites part de l'examen, que vous avez fait des bâtiments à vos ordres et des changemens que vous avez trouvé nécessaires parmi les commandans des galères, de l'ordre que vous établissez dans l'escadre et des soins que vous donnez pour hâter l'armement complet des divers bâtiments, tout ceci sert à me donner beaucoup de satisfaction, je vois avec plaisir que le Vice-Amiral Pouchkin Vous seconde en tout ce qui dépend de lui, je lui en ai marqué mon contentement. Je souhaite que le vent et toute sorte de bonheur seconde le zèle dont vous me donnez de nouveau des preuves aussi convainquantes. J'ai reçu ce matin du Gal. Comte Pouchkin que le Lt. Gal. Michelson est entré par Wehéra dans la Finlande Suédoise, qu'il a trouvé à Kiro un poste suédois retranché d'un millier d'hommes, ce poste a été forcé, le petit Bibikoff a été le premier dans le retranchement et a pris un des deux canons qu'on a pris; deux Majors, six officiers, 50 soldats suédois ont été fait prisonniers, 300 sont restés sur la place, le reste a voulu se sauver après avoir fait une rigoureuse défense, mais les Baschkirs (que les Suédois NB prennent pour des ogres) et les Kozakes, en ont fait un grand carnage dans l'eau et dans le bois. Michelson s'est avancé jusqu'à Christine d'òu il est allé vers St. Michel òu se trouvent des magasins, mes nouvelles--ne vont que jusque là, elles sont du 31 Mai 1 et 2 Juin,Catherine's secretary Khrapovitsky noted in his diary on 2 June 1789: 'Получено известие, что 31 Мая Михельсон, пошед к Христине, в пяти верстах от границы нашей, при деревне Кири: разбил 1000 Шведов, взял две пушки и пошел далее' ('News was received that on 31 May Mikhelson approached Khristina, and five miles from our border, by the village of Kiro, defeated 1000 Swedes, took two cannon, and moved on'). On 4 June he noted: 'Михельсон 1-го Июня занял Христину и пошел к Сант-Михелю' ('Mikhelson on the 1st of June occupied Khristina and set off for Sant-Mikhel'). Bad news of Mikhelson's defeat at Parosalmi arrived on 7 June. (Dnevnik A.V. Khrapovitskago, pp. 287-88.) nous voila donc à ce qu'il parait établis dans la Finlande Suédoise et le corps Suédois de Savelan parait etre coupé, le Gal. Major Schultz doit l'attaquer ces jours ci. Adieu bon voyage et bonne fortune; j'oubliais de Vous dire que nous avons encore des nouvelles qui paraissent assez sûres, comme quoi la grande flotte suédoise est dans un si mauvais état qu'un homme du métier fort entendu doit avoir dit qu'il faudrait être fou pour la mener à l'ennemi.Brückner, in his history of the Russo-Swedish War, cites this letter as evidence of Nassau-Siegen's willingness to inform Catherine of all the problems with the Russian navy and of his efforts improve the state of the Kronstadt flottila. At the start of the 1789 campaign, the Russians had 36 ships of the line and 20 fregates in Reval/Tallinn and Kronstadt, with 10 ships of the line and 3 fregates in Copenhagen; the Swedes had only 21 ships of the line and 9 fregates. (Brückner, Voina Rossii so Shvetsiei, pp. 176-77.) Catherine's secretary Khrapovitsky noted on 7 June 1789 that Prince Nassau had left Kronstadt the day before (i.e. 6 June) at 11 p.m. He added on 9 June that Nassau was being held back by contrary winds. (Dnevnik A.V. Khrapovitskago, pp. 287-88.)

I received yesterday your letter dated from Kronstadt harbour on 3 June, by which you inform me of the inspection that you carried out of the vessels under your command; and of the changes that you have found necessary among the commanders of the galleys; of the order that you are establishing in the squadron; and of your care to hurry on the complete armament of the various vessels. All this gives me much satisfaction. I see with pleasure that Vice-Admiral Pushkin is assisting you in every way he can: I have let him know that I am pleased. I hope that the wind and happy chance of all kinds come to the aid of the zeal of which you are once again giving me such convincing proof. I received this morning from the Gen. Count Pushkin [news] that Lt. Gen. Mikhelson has entered Swedish Finland via Wehéra. He found at Kiro a Swedish post defended by a thousand men. They took the post by force: the little Bibikov was the first one into the trench and took one of the two cannons that were taken. Two majors, six officers, and 50 Swedish soldiers were taken prisoner; 300 were left lying on the field; the rest wanted to flee after making a rigorous defence, but the Bashkirs (whom, NB., the Swedes take for ogres) and Cossacks massacred them in the water and in the woods. Mikhelson has advanced to Ristiina, whence he has gone towards Mikkeli, where stores can be found. My news goes only so far: it is from 31 May, 1 and 2 June. We are therefore, it seems, well established in Swedish Finland, and the Swedish corps from Savelan seems to be cut off. Major-Gen. Schulz is to attack it soon. Farewell, safe travels, and good luck. I almost forgot to tell you that we also have seemingly reliable news that the large Swedish flottila is in such a bad state that a very knowledgeable man of the trade is thought to have said, 'you would have to be mad to take it against the enemy'..
